\title{colabfit\sphinxhyphen{}tools}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{index::doc}}
\noindent{\hspace*{\fill}\sphinxincludegraphics[width=200\sphinxpxdimen,height=200\sphinxpxdimen]{{colabfit-logo}.png}\hspace*{\fill}}



\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit\sphinxhyphen{}tools}} is a package for constructing, manipulating, and
exploring datasets for data\sphinxhyphen{}driven interatomic potentials. This package is part
of the \sphinxhref{https://colabfit.openkim.org/}{ColabFit project} at the University of
Minnesota.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Despite the rapidly increasing popularity of data\sphinxhyphen{}driven interatomic
potentials (DDIPs), training data for these models has historically been
difficult to obtain and work with. Data is often stored in internally\sphinxhyphen{}developed
formats, insufficiently documented, and not made readily available to the
public.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit\_tools}} aims to address these problems by defining a standard
method for representing DDIP training datasets programatically, and providing
software tools for manipulating these representations.


\chapter{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{overview:overview}}\label{\detokenize{overview::doc}}

\section{Dataset Standard}
\label{\detokenize{overview:dataset-standard}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Dataset}}}}} class was designed to be able to
be as flexible as possible to incorporate different types of data
(computational/experimental) while also making the datasets efficient to query,
store, and manipulate. A {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Dataset}}}}} is constructed using five core data
structures:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}}}} (CO):}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
The information necessary to uniquely define the input to a calculation
(e.g., atomic types, positions, lattice vectors, constraints, …)

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{property:colabfit.tools.property.Property}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Property}}}}} (PR):}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
The outputs from a calculation (e.g., DFT\sphinxhyphen{}computed
energies/forces/stresses)

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{property_settings:colabfit.tools.property_settings.PropertySettings}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PropertySettings}}}}} (PSO):}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Additional metadata that useful for setting up the calculation (e.g.,
software version, input files, …)

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration_set:colabfit.tools.configuration_sets.ConfigurationSet}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ConfigurationSet}}}}} (CS):}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
An object defining a group of
{\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}}}} instances and
providing useful metadata for organizing datasets (e.g., “Snapshots from a
molecular dynamics run at 1000K”)

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{{\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Dataset}}}}} (DS):}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
The top\sphinxhyphen{}level dataset, which aggregates information up from the
configuration sets and sub\sphinxhyphen{}datasets for improved discoverability

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\capstart

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{ds_diagram}.png}
\caption{A diagram showing the relationship between the five core data structures}\label{\detokenize{overview:id1}}\end{figure}


\chapter{Getting started}
\label{\detokenize{getting_started:getting-started}}\label{\detokenize{getting_started::doc}}

\section{Installation}
\label{\detokenize{getting_started:installation}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Currently, installation is only supported using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pip}} to install directly
from the private GitHub repository.


\subsection{Using pip}
\label{\detokenize{getting_started:using-pip}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }pip install git+https://\PYGZlt{}username\PYGZus{}or\PYGZus{}pat\PYGZgt{}@github.com/colabfit/colabfit\PYGZhy{}tools.git
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that since \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit\sphinxhyphen{}tools}} is currently still a private project,
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textless{}username\_or\_pat\textgreater{}}} must either be your GitHub username (if you have access to the repository) or a
Personal Access Token that has appropriate permissions.


\chapter{Examples}
\label{\detokenize{examples:examples}}\label{\detokenize{examples::doc}}

\section{Basic example}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:basic-example}}\label{\detokenize{basic_example::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This example corresponds to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit/examples/basic\_example.ipynb}}
Jupyter notebook in the GitHub repo, which can be run in Google Colab.


\subsection{Creating a Dataset from scratch}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:creating-a-dataset-from-scratch}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Initialize the Dataset and add basic metadata.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{colabfit}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{tools}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{dataset} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Dataset}

\PYG{n}{dataset} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Dataset}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{example}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{authors} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{J. E. Lennard\PYGZhy{}Jones}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{]}

\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{links} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John\PYGZus{}Lennard\PYGZhy{}Jones}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{p}{]}

\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{description} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{This is an example dataset}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Adding Configurations}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:adding-configurations}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Load the configurations onto the Dataset by either manually constructing the
Configurations and assigning them to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configurations}} attribute, or
using {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.load_data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{load\_data()}}}}}, which calls a pre\sphinxhyphen{}made Converter and
returns a list of Configuration objects.


\subsubsection{Manually}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:manually}}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{numpy} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{np}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{ase} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Atoms}

\PYG{n}{images} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{i} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n+nb}{range}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{atoms} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Atoms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{H}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{positions}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{random}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{random}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{atoms}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{configuration\PYGZus{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{atoms}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dft\PYGZus{}energy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{i}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{i}
    \PYG{n}{atoms}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{arrays}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dft\PYGZus{}forces}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{random}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{normal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{size}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{i}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{n}{images}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{atoms}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{colabfit}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{tools}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{configuration} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Configuration}

\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{configurations} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}
    \PYG{n}{Configuration}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{from\PYGZus{}ase}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{atoms}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{atoms} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{images}
\PYG{p}{]}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Using \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{load\_data()}}}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:using-load-data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that the file\_format must be specified, and a name\_field (or None) should
be provided to specify the name of the loaded configurations.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{ase}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{io} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{write}

\PYG{n}{write}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/content/example.extxyz}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{images}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{colabfit}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{tools}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{dataset} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{load\PYGZus{}data}

\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{configurations} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{load\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{(}
        \PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/content/example.extxyz}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}format}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{xyz}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n}{name\PYGZus{}field}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n}{elements}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{H}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n}{default\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Applying labels to configurations}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:applying-labels-to-configurations}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Labels can be specified as lists or single strings (which will be wrapped in a list)
Metadata can be applied to individual configurations using labels. Labels are
applied by matching a regular expression to
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configuration.info{[}ASE\_NAME\_FIELD{]}}} for each configuration. Regex
mappings are provided by setting the configuration\_label\_regexes dictionary.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{configuration\PYGZus{}label\PYGZus{}regexes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{configuration\PYGZus{}[1\PYGZhy{}10]}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{small}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{.*}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{random}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Configuration sets using regexes}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:configuration-sets-using-regexes}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A {\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration_set:colabfit.tools.configuration_sets.ConfigurationSet}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ConfigurationSet}}}}} can be used to
create groups of configurations for organizational purposes. This can be done in
a similar manner to how configuration labels are applied, but using the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configuration\_set\_regexes}} dictionary. Note that a configuration may
exist in multiple sets at the same time.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{configuration\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}regexes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{configuration\PYGZus{}[1\PYGZhy{}499]}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:}   \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{The first configuration set}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{configuration\PYGZus{}[500\PYGZhy{}999]}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{The second configuration set}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Synchronizing the dataset}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:synchronizing-the-dataset}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Dataset is a pool of configurations and properties, where the configurations
are further organized by grouping them into configuration sets, and the
properties are linked to property settings. A Dataset then aggregates
information up from the configurations, properties, and property settings. In
order to ensure that the information applied by specifying
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configuration\_label\_regexes}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configuration\_set\_regexes}}, and
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property\_settings\_regexes}} are up\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}date, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dataset.resync()}}
should be called before performing critical operations like saving a Dataset.
Some core functions will call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{resync()}} automatically.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{resync}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Parsing the data}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:parsing-the-data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Parse the properties by specifying a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property\_map}}, which is a special
dictionary on a Dataset. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{usage:property-map}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Property map}}}} for more details.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{property\PYGZus{}map} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{default}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
        \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{energy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{field}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dft\PYGZus{}energy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{units}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{eV}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{forces}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{field}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dft\PYGZus{}forces}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{units}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{eV/Ang}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{parse\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{convert\PYGZus{}units}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{False}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{verbose}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Exploring the data}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:exploring-the-data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Use {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.get_data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_data()}}}}} to obtain a list of the
given property field where each element has been wrapped in a numpy array.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{energies} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{energy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{ravel}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{forces}   \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{forces}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{ravel}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Basic statistics can be obtained using
{\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.get_statistics}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_statistics()}}}}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Returns: \PYGZob{}\PYGZsq{}average\PYGZsq{}: ..., \PYGZsq{}std\PYGZsq{}: ..., \PYGZsq{}min\PYGZsq{}: ..., \PYGZsq{}max\PYGZsq{}:, ..., \PYGZsq{}average\PYGZus{}abs\PYGZsq{}: ...\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}statistics}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{energy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.plot_histograms}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{plot\_histograms()}}}}} function is useful
for quickly visualizing the distribution of your data.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{plot\PYGZus{}histograms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{energy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{forces}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Providing calculation metadata}
\label{\detokenize{basic_example:providing-calculation-metadata}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Metadata for computing properties can be provided by constructing a
{\hyperref[\detokenize{property_settings:colabfit.tools.property_settings.PropertySettings}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PropertySettings}}}}} object and matching
it to a property by regex matching on the property’s linked configurations.
It is good practice to always attach a PropertySettings object to every
Property to improve reproducibility of the data. It is especially useful to
include example input files using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{files}} field.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{colabfit}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{tools}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{property\PYGZus{}settings} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{PropertySettings}

\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{property\PYGZus{}settings\PYGZus{}regexes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{.*}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{n}{PropertySettings}\PYG{p}{(}
            \PYG{n}{method}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{VASP}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
            \PYG{n}{description}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{energy/force calculations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
            \PYG{n}{files}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/path/to/INCAR}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}
            \PYG{n}{labels}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{PBE}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{GGA}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\section{QM9 example}
\label{\detokenize{qm9:qm9-example}}\label{\detokenize{qm9::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This example will be used to highlight some of the more advanced features of the
Dataset class using the popular \sphinxhref{https://figshare.com/collections/Quantum\_chemistry\_structures\_and\_properties\_of\_134\_kilo\_molecules/978904}{QM9 dataset}.
It is suggested that you go through the {\hyperref[\detokenize{basic_example:basic-example}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{basic example}}}} first. The complete
code will not be shown in this example (for the complete code, see the Jupyter
notebook at \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit/examples/qm9.ipynb}}); instead, only the additional features will be
discussed here.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that this example assumes that the raw data has already been downloaded
using the following commands:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }mkdir qm9
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }\PYG{n+nb}{cd} qm9 \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}\PYGZam{}} wget \PYGZhy{}O dsgdb9nsd.xyz.tar.bz2 https://figshare.com/ndownloader/files/3195389 \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}\PYGZam{}} tar \PYGZhy{}xvjf dsgdb9nsd.xyz.tar.bz2
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Writing a custom property for QM9}
\label{\detokenize{qm9:writing-a-custom-property-for-qm9}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The QM9 dataset contains a large number of computed properties for each
Configuration, as documented in \sphinxhref{https://figshare.com/articles/dataset/Readme\_file\_Data\_description\_for\_Quantum\_chemistry\_structures\_and\_properties\_of\_134\_kilo\_molecules\_/1057641?backTo=/collections/Quantum\_chemistry\_structures\_and\_properties\_of\_134\_kilo\_molecules/978904}{its original README}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In order to preserve this information, a custom property can be defined
(see {\hyperref[\detokenize{usage:custom-properties}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Custom properties}}}} for more information).

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{qm9\PYGZus{}property\PYGZus{}definition} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{property\PYGZhy{}id}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{qm9\PYGZhy{}property}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{property\PYGZhy{}title}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{A, B, C, mu, alpha, homo, lumo, gap, r2, zpve, U0, U, H, G, Cv}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{property\PYGZhy{}description}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Geometries minimal in energy, corresponding harmonic frequencies, dipole moments, polarizabilities, along with energies, enthalpies, and free energies of atomization}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{a}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:}     \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{float}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{has\PYGZhy{}unit}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{extent}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{required}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{description}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Rotational constant A}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that a property definition is used for performing verification checks when
parsing the data. A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{property\_map}} must still be provided for specifying
\_how\_ to parse the data and what the units of the fields are.

\subsection{Defining a reader function}
\label{\detokenize{qm9:defining-a-reader-function}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Since the data in QM9 is not stored in a typical format (it uses an uncommon
modification to the typical XYZ format), it is necessary to use the
{\hyperref[\detokenize{converters:colabfit.tools.converters.FolderConverter}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FolderConverter}}}}} class, with a custom
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{reader()}} function.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\subsection{Writing to Markdown}
\label{\detokenize{qm9:writing-to-markdown}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To avoid having to re\sphinxhyphen{}process the raw data using \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{reader}}, and to provide
a cleaner storage format, {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.to_markdown}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{to\_markdown()}}}}}
can be used (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{usage:reading-writing-datasets-with-markdown}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Reading/writing Datasets with Markdown}}}} for more
details).

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{to\PYGZus{}markdown}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{n}{base\PYGZus{}folder}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{/content}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{html\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{README.md}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{+}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{.extxyz}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{data\PYGZus{}format}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{xyz}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Cleaning the dataset}
\label{\detokenize{qm9:cleaning-the-dataset}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Using the {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.plot_histograms}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{plot\_histograms()}}}}} and
{\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.get_statistics}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_statistics()}}}}} functions reveals that
the QM9 dataset has some outlying data entries.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]

\section{Si PRX GAP}
\label{\detokenize{si_prx_gap:si-prx-gap}}\label{\detokenize{si_prx_gap::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This example will be used to highlight some of the more advanced features of the
Dataset class using the popular \sphinxhref{https://www.repository.cam.ac.uk/handle/1810/317974}{Si GAP dataset}.
It is suggested that you go through the {\hyperref[\detokenize{basic_example:basic-example}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{basic example}}}} first. The complete
code will not be shown in this example (for the complete code, see the Jupyter
notebook at \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit/examples/si\_prx\_gap.ipynb}}); instead, only the additional features will be
discussed here.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that this example assumes that the raw data has already been downloaded
using the following commands:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }mkdir si\PYGZus{}prx\PYGZus{}gap
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }\PYG{n+nb}{cd} si\PYGZus{}prx\PYGZus{}gap \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}\PYGZam{}} wget \PYGZhy{}O Si\PYGZus{}PRX\PYGZus{}GAP.zip https://www.repository.cam.ac.uk/bitstream/handle/1810/317974/Si\PYGZus{}PRX\PYGZus{}GAP.zip?sequence\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m}{1}\PYG{p}{\PYGZam{}}\PYG{n+nv}{isAllowed}\PYG{o}{=}yield
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZdl{} }\PYG{n+nb}{cd} si\PYGZus{}prx\PYGZus{}gap \PYG{o}{\PYGZam{}\PYGZam{}} unzip Si\PYGZus{}PRX\PYGZus{}GAP.zip
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Loading from a file}
\label{\detokenize{si_prx_gap:loading-from-a-file}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This example uses {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.load_data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{load\_data()}}}}} to load the data
from an existing Extended XYZ file. Note that the raw data includes the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{config\_type}} field, which is used to generate the names of the loaded
Configurations. A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{default\_name}} is also provided to handle the
configurations that do not have a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{config\_type}} field.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{verbose=True}} is used here since the dataset is large enough to warrant a
progress bar.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{configurations} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{load\PYGZus{}data}\PYG{p}{(}
        \PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}path}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{./si\PYGZus{}prx\PYGZus{}gap/gp\PYGZus{}iter6\PYGZus{}sparse9k.xml.xyz}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}format}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{xyz}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n}{name\PYGZus{}field}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{config\PYGZus{}type}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} key in Configuration.info to use as the Configuration name}
        \PYG{n}{elements}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Si}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n}{default\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{,}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} default name with `name\PYGZus{}field` not found}
        \PYG{n}{verbose}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Manually constructed ConfigurationSets}
\label{\detokenize{si_prx_gap:manually-constructed-configurationsets}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Since this dataset was manually constructed by its authors, a large amount of
additional information has been provided to better identify the Configurations
(see Table I. in \sphinxhref{https://journals.aps.org/prx/abstract/10.1103/PhysRevX.8.041048}{the original paper}).
In order to retain this information, we define ConfigurationSets by regex
matching on the Configuration names (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{usage:building-configuration-sets}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Building configuration sets}}}} for
more details).

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{configuration\PYGZus{}set\PYGZus{}regexes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{isolated\PYGZus{}atom}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Reference atom}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{bt}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Beta\PYGZhy{}tin}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dia}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Diamond}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{sh}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Simple hexagonal}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{hex\PYGZus{}diamond}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Hexagonal diamond}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{bcc}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Body\PYGZhy{}centered\PYGZhy{}cubic}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{bc8}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{BC8}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{fcc}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Face\PYGZhy{}centered\PYGZhy{}cubic}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{hcp}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Hexagonal\PYGZhy{}close\PYGZhy{}packed}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{st12}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{ST12}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{liq}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Liquid}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{amorph}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Amorphous}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{surface\PYGZus{}001}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Diamond surface (001)}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{surface\PYGZus{}110}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Diamond surface (110)}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{surface\PYGZus{}111}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Diamond surface (111)}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{surface\PYGZus{}111\PYGZus{}pandey}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Pandey reconstruction of diamond (111) surface}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{surface\PYGZus{}111\PYGZus{}3x3\PYGZus{}das}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Dimer\PYGZhy{}adatom\PYGZhy{}stacking\PYGZhy{}fault (DAS) reconstruction}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{111adatom}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Configurations with adatom on (111) surface}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{crack\PYGZus{}110\PYGZus{}1\PYGZhy{}10}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Small (110) crack tip}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{crack\PYGZus{}111\PYGZus{}1\PYGZhy{}10}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Small (111) crack tip}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{decohesion}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Decohesion of diamond\PYGZhy{}structure Si along various directions}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{divacancy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Diamond divacancy configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{interstitial}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Diamond interstitial configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{screw\PYGZus{}disloc}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Si screw dislocation core}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{sp}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{sp bonded configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{sp2}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{sp2 bonded configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{vacancy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Diamond vacancy configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Manually applied Configuration labels}
\label{\detokenize{si_prx_gap:manually-applied-configuration-labels}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Similarly, this additional knowledge about the types of Configurations in the
dataset can be used to apply metadata labels to the Configurations, which is
useful for enabling querying over the data by future users. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{usage:applying-configuration-labels}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Applying Configuration labels}}}}

\subsection{Renaming Configuration fields}
\label{\detokenize{si_prx_gap:renaming-configuration-fields}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In order to ensure that {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.parse_data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parse\_data()}}}}} is
able to properly parse the data, the fields in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration.info}} and
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration.arrays}} should match those used in
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Dataset.property\_map}}. In the case of the Si GAP dataset, some of the
data has incorrectly labeled energy/force/virial fields, where it uses
“DFT\_*” instead of “dft\_*” (lowercase) like the rest of the Configurations. In
order to fix this, we use the
{\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.rename_configuration_field}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{rename\_configuration\_field()}}}}} function:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{rename\PYGZus{}configuration\PYGZus{}field}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{DFT\PYGZus{}energy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dft\PYGZus{}energy}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{rename\PYGZus{}configuration\PYGZus{}field}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{DFT\PYGZus{}force}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dft\PYGZus{}force}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{rename\PYGZus{}configuration\PYGZus{}field}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{DFT\PYGZus{}virial}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{dft\PYGZus{}virial}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Filtering based on XC\sphinxhyphen{}functional}
\label{\detokenize{si_prx_gap:filtering-based-on-xc-functional}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In the Si GAP dataset, some of the data was computed using a PBE functional,
and some was computed using a PW91 functional. This information is stored in the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{xc\_functional}} field of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration.info}} array.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{set}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get\PYGZus{}configuration\PYGZus{}field}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{xc\PYGZus{}functional}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} output: \PYGZob{}\PYGZsq{}PBE\PYGZsq{}, \PYGZsq{}PW91\PYGZsq{}\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A user may want to only work with subsets of the data that were computed with
the exact same DFT settings. To facilitate this, we break the original Dataset
into three separate datasets using the
{\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.filter}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{filter()}}}}} function (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{usage:filtering-a-dataset}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Filtering a Dataset}}}} for more details).

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{no\PYGZus{}xc\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{xc\PYGZus{}functional}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o+ow}{is} \PYG{k+kc}{None}
\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{pbe\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{xc\PYGZus{}functional}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{PBE}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}
\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{pw91\PYGZus{}data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{xc\PYGZus{}functional}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{k+kc}{None}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{==} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{PW91}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\chapter{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{usage:usage}}\label{\detokenize{usage::doc}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
have all of the special dictionaries described somewhere.

\end{itemize}


\section{Property map}
\label{\detokenize{usage:property-map}}\begin{description}
\item[{Note that the keys should be one of the following:}] \leavevmode\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The name of an OpenKIM Property Definition from the \sphinxhref{https://openkim.org/properties}{list of approved OpenKIM Property Definitions}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The name of a locally\sphinxhyphen{}defined property (see {\hyperref[\detokenize{usage:custom-properties}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Custom properties}}}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The string \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}default\textquotesingle{}}}. Note that \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textquotesingle{}default\textquotesingle{}}} means that an
existing property will be used with support for basic fields like
‘energy’, ‘forces’, and ‘stress’.

\end{enumerate}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
‘field’ is used to specify the key for extracting the property from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration.info()}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuartion.arrays()}}.
{\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.parse_data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parse\_data()}}}}} will extract the fields
provided in property\_map from the configuration, and store them as Property
objects in the dataset.data list. If a custom property is used, the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{custom\_definitions}} dictionary of a
Dataset must be updated to either point to the local EDN file or a Python
dictionary representation of the contents of the EDN file. See
{\hyperref[\detokenize{usage:custom-properties}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Custom properties}}}} for more details

build configuration sets.

\section{Visualization}

\section{Core classes}
\label{\detokenize{core_classes:core-classes}}\label{\detokenize{core_classes::doc}}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{configuration:module-colabfit.tools.configuration}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!colabfit.tools.configuration@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.configuration}}\index{colabfit.tools.configuration@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.configuration}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A {\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}}}} stores all of the information about an atomic
structure. The {\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}}}} class inherits from the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ase.Atoms}}
class, and populates some required fields in its \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Atoms.info}} dictionary.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The most common use\sphinxhyphen{}case for building {\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}}}} objects is to use
the {\hyperref[\detokenize{converters:colabfit.tools.converters.BaseConverter.load}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{load()}}}}} method of a
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit.tools.BaseConverter}} instance, which will call
{\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration.from_ase}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration.from\_ase()}}}}} on an existing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ase.Atoms}} object.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{colabfit}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{tools}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{converters} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{EXYZConverter}

\PYG{n}{converter} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{EXYZConverter}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{configurations} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{converter}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{load}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{configuration:configuration}}\label{\detokenize{configuration::doc}}\index{Configuration (class in colabfit.tools.configuration)@\spxentry{Configuration}\spxextra{class in colabfit.tools.configuration}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w}{  }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit.tools.configuration.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{labels}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{constraints}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{*}\DUrole{n}{args}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Configuration is an extension of an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ase.Atoms}} object that is
guaranteed to have the following fields in its \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{info}} dictionary:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ATOMS\_ID\_FIELD}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ATOMS\_NAME\_FIELD}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ATOMS\_LABELS\_FIELD}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ATOMS\_CONSTRAINTS\_FIELD}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Constructs a Configuration. Calls \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ase.Atoms.\_\_init\_\_()}}, then
populates the additional required fields.
\index{\_\_hash\_\_() (colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration method)@\spxentry{\_\_hash\_\_()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration.__hash__}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_hash\_\_}}}{}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Generates a hash for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{self}} by hashing its length, constraints,
positions, (atomic) numbers, simulation cell, and periodic
boundary conditions

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{\_\_init\_\_() (colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration method)@\spxentry{\_\_init\_\_()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration.__init__}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_init\_\_}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{labels}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{constraints}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{*}\DUrole{n}{args}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Constructs a Configuration. Calls \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ase.Atoms.\_\_init\_\_()}}, then
populates the additional required fields.

\end{fulllineitems}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{property:module-colabfit.tools.property}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!colabfit.tools.property@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.property}}\index{colabfit.tools.property@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.property}!module@\spxentry{module}}

A {\hyperref[\detokenize{property:colabfit.tools.property.Property}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Property}}}}} is usually extracted from a
{\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}}}} object using the
{\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.parse_data}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parse\_data()}}}}} of a {\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Dataset()}}}}} object.


\subsection{Property}
\label{\detokenize{property:property}}\label{\detokenize{property::doc}}\index{Property (class in colabfit.tools.property)@\spxentry{Property}\spxextra{class in colabfit.tools.property}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{property:colabfit.tools.property.Property}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w}{  }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit.tools.property.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Property}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{name}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{configurations}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{property\_map}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{settings}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{edn}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{instance\_id}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{1}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{convert\_units}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Property is used to store the results of some kind of calculation or
experiment, and should be mapped to an \sphinxhref{https://openkim.org/doc/schema/properties-framework/}{OpenKIM Property Definition}. Best
practice is for the Property to also point to one or more
PropertySettings objects that fully define the conditions under which the
Property was obtained.
\index{edn (colabfit.tools.property.Property attribute)@\spxentry{edn}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.property.Property attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{property:colabfit.tools.property.Property.edn}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{edn}}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A dictionary defining an OpenKIM Property Instance in EDN format.
For more details, see the \sphinxhref{https://openkim.org/doc/schema/properties-framework/}{OpenKIM Property Framework} documentation.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Type}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
dict

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{property\_map (colabfit.tools.property.Property attribute)@\spxentry{property\_map}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.property.Property attribute}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{property:colabfit.tools.property.Property.property_map}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{property\_map}}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
key = a string that can be used as a key like \sphinxtitleref{self.edn{[}key{]}}
value = A sub\sphinxhyphen{}dictionary with the following keys:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{field}}:}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
A field name used to access \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration.info}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration.arrays}}

\end{description}

\item {} \begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{units}}:}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
A string matching one of the units names in \sphinxhref{https://wiki.fysik.dtu.dk/ase/ase/units.html}{ase.units}.
These units will be used to convert the given units to eV,
Angstrom, a.m.u., Kelvin, … For compound units (e.g. “eV/Ang”), the string will be split on
‘*’ and ‘/’. The raw data will be multiplied by the first unit
and anything preceded by a ‘*’. It will be divided by anything
preceded by a ‘/’.

\end{description}

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Type}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
dict

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{property_settings:module-colabfit.tools.property_settings}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!colabfit.tools.property\_settings@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.property\_settings}}\index{colabfit.tools.property\_settings@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.property\_settings}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
It is best practice to attach a {\hyperref[\detokenize{property_settings:colabfit.tools.property_settings.PropertySettings}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PropertySettings}}}}} object to a
{\hyperref[\detokenize{property:colabfit.tools.property.Property}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Property}}}}} instance in order to better document
the conditions under which the property was computed. This would often include
information such as the DFT software package, a description of the calculation,
and an example file for running the calculation.


\subsection{PropertySettings}

\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

Default is False.

\index{clean() (colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method)@\spxentry{clean()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.clean}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{clean}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{verbose}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Uses hashing to compare the configurations of all properties and check
for duplicate configurations.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{dataset\_from\_config\_sets() (colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method)@\spxentry{dataset\_from\_config\_sets()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.dataset_from_config_sets}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{dataset\_from\_config\_sets}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{cs\_ids}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{exclude}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{verbose}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns a new dataset that only contains the specified configuration
sets.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{cs\_ids}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} The index of the configuration set(s) to use for building the
new dataset. If \sphinxtitleref{self} is a parent dataset, then \sphinxtitleref{cs\_ids} shoud
either be a 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple or a list of 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuples (i, j), where the
configuration sets will be indexed as
\sphinxtitleref{dataset.data{[}i{]}.configuration\_sets{[}j{]}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{exclude}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} If False, builds a new dataset using all of the configuration
sets \_except\_ those specified by \sphinxtitleref{cs\_ids}. Default is False.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{verbose}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} If True, prints progress. Default is False

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
The new dataset. If \sphinxtitleref{self} is a parent dataset, then the new
dataset will also be a parent dataset.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
ds ({\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset}]{\sphinxcrossref{Dataset}}})

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{filter() (colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method)@\spxentry{filter()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.filter}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{filter}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{filter\_type}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{filter\_fxn}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{copy}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{verbose}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A helper function for filtering on a Dataset. A filter is specified by
providing  a \sphinxtitleref{filter\_type} and a \sphinxtitleref{filter\_fxn}. In the case of a parent
dataset, the filter is applied to each of the children individually.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Examples:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Filter based on configuration name}
\PYG{n}{regex} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{re}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{compile}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{example\PYGZus{}name.*}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{filtered\PYGZus{}dataset} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{configurations}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{c}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{regex}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{search}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{c}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{ATOMS\PYGZus{}NAME\PYGZus{}FIELD}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Filter based on maximum force component}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{numpy} \PYG{k}{as} \PYG{n+nn}{np}

\PYG{n}{filtered\PYGZus{}dataset} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{dataset}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{filter}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{data}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{k}{lambda} \PYG{n}{p}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{max}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{p}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{edn}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{unrelaxed\PYGZhy{}potential\PYGZhy{}forces}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{source\PYGZhy{}value}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZlt{}} \PYG{l+m+mf}{1.0}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{filter\_type}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
One of ‘configurations’ or ‘data’.
\begin{description}
\item[{If \sphinxtitleref{filter\_type == ‘configurations’}:}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Filters on configurations, and returns a dataset with only
the configurations and their linked properties.

\item[{If \sphinxtitleref{filter\_type == ‘data’}:}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
Filters on properties, and returns a dataset with only the
properties and their linked configurations.

\end{description}


\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{filter\_fxn}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{callable}}) \textendash{} A callable function to use as \sphinxtitleref{filter(filter\_fxn)}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{copy}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} If True, deep copies all dataset attributes before returning
filtered results. Default is False.

\end{itemize}

\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Dataset object constructed by applying the specified filter,
extracting any objects linked to the filtered object, then
copying over \sphinxtitleref{property\_map}, \sphinxtitleref{configuration\_label\_regexes},
\sphinxtitleref{configuration\_set\_regexes}, and \sphinxtitleref{property\_settings\_regexes}.

\item[{Return type}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
dataset ({\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset}]{\sphinxcrossref{Dataset}}})

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.flatten}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{flatten}}}{}{}~\begin{description}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\end{itemize}

\index{get\_data() (colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method)@\spxentry{get\_data()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.get_data}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_data}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{property\_field}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{cs\_ids}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{exclude}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{concatenate}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{ravel}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns a list of properties obtained by looping over \sphinxtitleref{self.data} and
extracting the desired field if it exists on the property.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that if the field does not exist on the property, that property
will be skipped. This means that if there are multiple properties linked
to a single configuration, \sphinxtitleref{len(get\_data(…))} will not be the same as
\sphinxtitleref{len(self.configurations)}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{property\_field}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The string key used to extract the property values from the
Property objects

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{cs\_ids}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{int}}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{ or }}\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The integers specifying the configuration sets to obtain the
data from. Default is None, which returns data from all
configuration sets.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If \sphinxtitleref{self} is a base dataset, then \sphinxtitleref{cs\_ids} should be a list of
integers used for indexing \sphinxtitleref{self.configuration\_sets}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If \sphinxtitleref{self} is a parent dataset, then \sphinxtitleref{cs\_ids} should be a list of
2\sphinxhyphen{}tuples \sphinxtitleref{(i, j)} where a configuration set will be indexed
using \sphinxtitleref{self.data{[}i{]}.configuration\_sets{[}j{]}}.


\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{exclude}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} Only to be used when \sphinxtitleref{cs\_ids} is not None. If \sphinxtitleref{exclude==True},
then data is only returned for the configuration sets that are
\_not\_ in \sphinxtitleref{cs\_ids}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{concatenate}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} If True, calls np.concatenate() on the list before returning.
Default is False.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ravel}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} If True, calls np.concatenate() on the list before returning.
Default is False.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Returns a list of Numpy arrays that were constructed by calling
{[}np.atleast\_1d(d{[}property\_field{]}{[}‘source\sphinxhyphen{}value’{]}) for d in self.data{]}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{get\_statistics() (colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method)@\spxentry{get\_statistics()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.get_statistics}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_statistics}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{property\_field}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Builds an list by extracting the values of \sphinxtitleref{property\_field} for
each entry in the dataset, wrapping them in a numpy array, and
concatenating them all together. Then returns statistics on the
resultant array.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Returns}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
\begin{description}
\item[{results (dict)::}] \leavevmode\begin{description}
\item[{..code\sphinxhyphen{}block::}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
\{‘average’: np.average(data), ‘std’: np.std(data), ‘min’: np.min(data), ‘max’: np.max(data), ‘average\_abs’: np.average(np.abs(data))\}

\end{description}

\end{description}


\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{merge() (colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method)@\spxentry{merge()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.merge}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{merge}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{other}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{clean}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Merges the new and current Datasets. Note that the current data
supersedes any incoming data. This means that if incoming data points
to an existing configuration, the incoming data is not added to the
Dataset because it is assumed that the existing data pointing to the
same configuration is the more important version.
\begin{description}
\item[{The following additional changes are made to the incoming data:}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Configurations are renamed to prepend the name of their datasets

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
All regexes are renamed as f”\textasciicircum{}\{other.name\}\_.*\{regex\}”

\end{itemize}

\end{description}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{other}} ({\hyperref[\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{Dataset}}}}}) \textendash{} The new dataset to be added to the existing one.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{clean}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} If True, checks for duplicates after merging. Default is False.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{parse\_data() (colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method)@\spxentry{parse\_data()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.Dataset.parse_data}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{parse\_data}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{convert\_units}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{verbose}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Re\sphinxhyphen{}constructs \sphinxtitleref{self.data} by building a list of Property objects using
\sphinxtitleref{self.property\_map} and \sphinxtitleref{self.configurations}. Modifies \sphinxtitleref{self.data} in
place. If \sphinxtitleref{convert\_units==True}, then the units in \sphinxtitleref{self.property\_map}
are also updated.

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{data\_format}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Format to use for data file. Default is ‘xyz’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{name\_field}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The name of the field that should be used to generate
configuration names

\end{itemize}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:module-colabfit.tools.dataset}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!colabfit.tools.dataset@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.dataset}}\index{colabfit.tools.dataset@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.dataset}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{load\_data() (in module colabfit.tools.dataset)@\spxentry{load\_data()}\spxextra{in module colabfit.tools.dataset}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{dataset:colabfit.tools.dataset.load_data}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit.tools.dataset.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{load\_data}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{file\_path}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{file\_format}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{name\_field}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{elements}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{default\_name}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}\textquotesingle{}}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{labels\_field}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{reader}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{glob\_string}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{verbose}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Loads configurations as a list of ase.Atoms objects.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{file\_path}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Path to the file or folder containing the data

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{file\_format}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} A string for specifying the type of Converter to use when loading
the configurations. Allowed values are ‘xyz’, ‘extxyz’, ‘cfg’, or
‘folder’.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{name\_field}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Key name to use to access \sphinxtitleref{ase.Atoms.info{[}\textless{}name\_field\textgreater{}{]}} to
obtain the name of a configuration one the atoms have been
loaded from the data file. Note that if
\sphinxtitleref{file\_format == ‘folder’}, \sphinxtitleref{name\_field} will be set to ‘name’.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{elements}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} A list of strings of element types

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{default\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} Default name to be used if \sphinxtitleref{name\_field==None}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{labels\_field}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} Key name to use to access \sphinxtitleref{ase.Atoms.info{[}\textless{}labels\_field\textgreater{}{]}} to
obtain the labels that should be applied to the configuration. This
field should contain a comma\sphinxhyphen{}separated list of strings

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{reader}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{callable}}) \textendash{} An optional function for loading configurations from a file. Only
used for \sphinxtitleref{file\_format == ‘folder’}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{glob\_string}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} A string to use with \sphinxtitleref{Path(file\_path).rglob(glob\_string)} to
generate a list of files to be passed to \sphinxtitleref{self.reader}. Only used
for \sphinxtitleref{file\_format == ‘folder’}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{verbose}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} If True, prints progress bar.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
All other keyword arguments will be passed with
\sphinxtitleref{converter.load(…, **kwargs)}

\end{fulllineitems}



\section{Additional tools}
\label{\detokenize{additional_tools:additional-tools}}\label{\detokenize{additional_tools::doc}}\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{converters:module-colabfit.tools.converters}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!colabfit.tools.converters@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.converters}}\index{colabfit.tools.converters@\spxentry{colabfit.tools.converters}!module@\spxentry{module}}

\subsection{Converter}
\label{\detokenize{converters:converter}}\label{\detokenize{converters::doc}}\index{BaseConverter (class in colabfit.tools.converters)@\spxentry{BaseConverter}\spxextra{class in colabfit.tools.converters}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{converters:colabfit.tools.converters.BaseConverter}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w}{  }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit.tools.converters.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{BaseConverter}}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Converter is used to load a list of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ase.Atoms}} objects and convert
them to {\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration:colabfit.tools.configuration.Configuration}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}}}} objects.
\index{load() (colabfit.tools.converters.BaseConverter method)@\spxentry{load()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.converters.BaseConverter method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{converters:colabfit.tools.converters.BaseConverter.load}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{load}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{file\_path}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{name\_field}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{elements}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{default\_name}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\textquotesingle{}\textquotesingle{}}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{labels\_field}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{verbose}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Loads a list of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration}}
objects.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{file\_path}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The path to the data files.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{name\_field}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The key for accessing the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{info}} dictionary of a
Configuration object to return the name of the Configuration.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{elements}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{list}}) \textendash{} A list of strings of element names. Order matters or file types
where a mapping from atom number to element type isn’t provided
(e.g., CFG files).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{default\_name}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The name to attach to the Configuration object if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{name\_field}}
does not exist on \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Configuration.info}}. Default is an
empty string.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{labels\_field}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{str}}) \textendash{} The key for accessing the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{info}} dictionary of a
Configuration object that returns a set of string labels.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{verbose}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{bool}}) \textendash{} If True, prints the loading progress. Default is False.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\index{FolderConverter (class in colabfit.tools.converters)@\spxentry{FolderConverter}\spxextra{class in colabfit.tools.converters}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{converters:colabfit.tools.converters.FolderConverter}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w}{  }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{colabfit.tools.converters.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{FolderConverter}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{reader}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This converter serves as a generic template from loading configurations from
collections of files. It is useful for loading from storage formats like
JSON, HDF5, or nested folders of output files from DFT codes.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{reader}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{callable}}) \textendash{} A function that takes in a file path and returns an \sphinxtitleref{ase.Atoms}
object with the relevant data in \sphinxtitleref{atoms.info} and
\sphinxtitleref{atoms.arrays}.

\end{description}\end{quote}
\index{\_\_init\_\_() (colabfit.tools.converters.FolderConverter method)@\spxentry{\_\_init\_\_()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.converters.FolderConverter method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{converters:colabfit.tools.converters.FolderConverter.__init__}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\_\_init\_\_}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{reader}}}{}~\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Parameters}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{reader}} (\sphinxstyleliteralemphasis{\sphinxupquote{callable}}) \textendash{} A function that takes in a file path and returns an \sphinxtitleref{ase.Atoms}
object with the relevant data in \sphinxtitleref{atoms.info} and
\sphinxtitleref{atoms.arrays}.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{\_load() (colabfit.tools.converters.FolderConverter method)@\spxentry{\_load()}\spxextra{colabfit.tools.converters.FolderConverter method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{converters:colabfit.tools.converters.FolderConverter._load}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{\_load}}}{\emph{\DUrole{n}{file\_path}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{name\_field}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{elements}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{default\_name}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{labels\_field}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{verbose}}, \emph{\DUrole{n}{glob\_string}}, \emph{\DUrole{o}{**}\DUrole{n}{kwargs}}}{}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Arguments are the same as for other converters, but with the following
changes:
\begin{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{file\_path (str):}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
The path to the parent directory containing the data files.

\item[{glob\_string (str):}] \leavevmode
\sphinxAtStartPar
A string to use with \sphinxtitleref{Path(file\_path).rglob(glob\_string)} to
generate a list of files to be passed to \sphinxtitleref{self.reader}

\end{description}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
All additional kwargs will be passed to the reader function as
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{self.reader(..., **kwargs)}}

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{Transform}
\label{\detokenize{transformations:transform}}\label{\detokenize{transformations::doc}}\index{BaseTransform (class in colabfit.tools.transformations)@\spxentry{BaseTransform}\spxextra{class in colabfit.tools.transformations}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A Transform is used for processing raw data before loading it into a
Dataset. For example for things like subtracting off a reference energy or
extracting the 6\sphinxhyphen{}component version of the cauchy stress from a 3x3 matrix.
